The algorithm for division of polynomials is analogous to the algorithm of long division learned in elementary school. We shall start by understanding the basic ideas behind long division and then use them in the division of polynomials.

title: pol_division
text:
Exemplo 1: \(22/3\)


O múltiplo de \(3\) mais perto de \(22\) é \(7\).
Como \(7\times 3 = 21\), a subtracção \(22-21\) dá-nos \(1\).
Dado que \(1\) não é divisível por \(3\), este é considerado o resto da divisão.
Concluímos que: \(22 = 7\times 3 +1\).


Uma forma alternativa de calcular \(22/3\)
O quociente de inteiros \(p/d\) é o número que nos diz quantas vezes \(d\) cabe em \(p\), esta é a ideia chave!
Por sua vez este número diz-nos quem é maior, \(p\) ou \(d\)?

Quando \(p/d<1\) então \(d\) é maior.
Quando \(p/d=1\) são o mesmo número.
Quando o quociente é maior do que \(1\), significa que \(p\) é maior.

Foque-mo-nos no último caso.
Considera \(22\) e \(3\), repara que, \(3\), cabe \(7\) vezes em \(22\) pois \(3\times 7=21\). Concluímos então que \(22=7\cdot 3+1\), o resto \(1\) é a pequena correcção que falta a \(3\times 7\) para chegar a \(22\). A formula
\[
22=7\cdot 3 +1
\]
relacciona os números \(22\) e \(3\). Observa, no lado esquerdo um único número \(22\) e no lado direito \(7\times 3 +1\) as peças que o compõem.
Usando em geral esta decomposição tem as seguintes características:
Sejam \(p\) e \(d\) dois interiros. Então existe um inteiro \(r\) tal que \(0\leq r<d\) e um inteiro \(q\geq 0\) tal que:
\[
p=qd+r
\]
A ideia chave para realizar o calculo \(22/3\) é ver quantas vezes \(3\) cabe dentro de \(22\), por outras palavras, a ideia chave é encontrar o número \(q\) que garante a correcção \(r\) mais pequena (neste caso inferior a \(3\)), ou seja:
\[
22=q\cdot 3+r \qquad 0\leq r<3
\]
Como é que encontramos este número \(q\)? Resposta: Adivinhamos a resposta. Eis alguns exemplos:

E se \(q=6\)?
Substituindo na equação obtemos \(22=6\cdot 3+r\) o que é equivalente a\(r=22-18=4\). Da do que o resto não está entre \(0\) e \(3\), temos de parti-lo em partes mais pequenas:
\[
4 = q'\cdot 3 + r' \qquad 0\leq r' < 3
\]
Adivinhando que a resposta é \(q'=1\), obtemos \(r'=1\).
Em conclusão:
\[
22 = 6\times 3 + 1\times 3 + +1
\]
Ou seja:
\[
22 = 7\times 3 +1
\]
E se \(q=7\)?
Substituindo obtemos
\[
22 = 7\times 3 + r
\]
o que é equivalente a
\[
r = 22-21 = 1
\]
Concluímos que
\[
22 = 7\times 3 +1
\]
E se \(q=8\) ?
\[
22 = 8\times 3 + r \iff r=22-24 =-2
\]
Então
\[
22 = 8\times 3 -2
\]
Como o resto é negativo e precisamos dele positivo, vamos corrigir esta expressão adicionado \(0=3-3\):
\[
22 = 8\times 3 -2 +3-3 = (8-1)\times 3 +(3-2) = 7\times 3 +1
\]

title: pol_division
text:
Example 2: \(1001/12\)
Let us consider now a more sophisticated division \(1001/12\), how do we argue as in elementary school?
We would first ask:





Implicit in this question is the observation that \(1001 = 100\times 10 +1\).
The answer is obviously \(8\):





Look the position of the \(8\) is at the \(10\)’s place (under the \(1\) in \(12\)).
Multiplying now \(8\times 12 = 96\) we place it under the \(10\)’s place of \(1001\):





Now we remove from \(1001\) the value \(96 \times 10\) since \(96\) sits under the \(10\)’s place, the result is a \(4\) under the \(10\)’s place:





Removing \(96\times 10\) from \(1000\) yields the \(4 \times 10\), but removing \(96\times 10\) from \(1001\) gives \(4\times 10 +1\), thus we drop the \(1\) in \(1001\) and ask:





The answer is \(3\), we place it under the \(1\)’s place (under the \(2\) in \(12\)):





Multiplying \(3\times 12\) we obtain \(36\), we write it under the \(1\)’s place of \(41\):





Removing from the current remainder \(41\) this \(36\) gives:





Combining all these removals from \(1001\) we conclude:





What we have been computing in elementary school with this dividion algorithm is the solution \(q\) and \(r\) of the equation:
\[
1001 = q \times 12 + r \qquad 0\leq r<12
\]
There are many paths and we follow then in stages.
The extreme of simplicity is to immediately guess the answer as \(q=83\) and \(r=5\), you do this if you are a genius, a path of a single step.
Depending on the quality of our guesses we increase the number of steps.
Guess 1:
Observing that \(1001=600+401\) and \(5\times 12 =60\) we guess that actual solution \(q\) is close to \(10\times 5\):
\[
600+401 = \overbrace{10 \times 5}^{q} \times 12 +r
\]
with the remainder \(r=401\). Since it is not between \(0\) and \(12\) we can do better. Lets break \(401\) by guessing what is \(q'\) and \(r'\) such that:
\[
401 = q'\times 12 + r' \qquad 0\leq r'<12
\]
We think \(q'=3\times10\) is a good solution since \(q'\times 12 = 360\), as a result the remainder is \(r'=401-360=41\)
Not ideal, we want it at most \(12\). Therefore we again break into pieces:
\[
41 = q''\times 12 + r'' \qquad 0\leq r''<12
\]
With the guess \(q''=3\) and the current remainder is just \(r''=41-36=5\).
Note, finally!! We have a remainder smaller than \(12\).
Collecting out calculations we have:
\[
1001 = \overbrace{(10 \times 5 + 3\times 10 + 3)}^{q=83}\times 12 + 5
\]






Commentary



When guessing \(q\) it is useful to break \(p\) (in the example above \(p=1001\)) into a large and a smaller part.
\[
p=[\text{large part}]+[\text{small part}]
\]
And then guess the best you can the \(q\) that cancels the large part.
There are many ways to break \(p\), experience will tell you what is ideal or not.

title: I.5
text:
Este sutram contêm ideias já mencionadas em sutrams anteriores.
Achei os comentários nos 2 primeiros paragrafos desnecessariamente elaboradas e em duas ocasiões até contraditórias.
Fica-se sem se saber se criação se refere ao universo físico e mental ou se a palavra criação se refere apenas à criação de uma onda.
Em duas ocasiões o autor numa parte da frase diz que a “Consciência Nuclear…. é imutável” ou “…purusa é imóvel e imutável” mas o contexto em que estes excertos estão mergulhados sugere (em meu entender) que prakrti os transforma, donde não podem ser imutáveis.
O autor procura também descrever uma forma simples o facto de a Consciência ser infinita e intemporal dizendo que “como não conseguimos conceber mentalmente as infinidades dizemos que”:

a consciência é ao mesmo tempo amarrada e não amarrada
temporal como intemporal
é livre mesmo quando parece pertencer à escravidão
a criação (do universo ou objectos da consciência) é eterna ou seja tem um ponto partida intemporal. A esse ponto partida chamamos kamabiija.

Apesar da complicação, eis a ideia central dos dois primeiros paragrafos:
A Consciência é dotada do desejo de se expressar (icchasshakti), esse desejo desencadeia a acção da força prakti a moldar purusa.
De que forma é que prakrti molda purusa? Molda-a formando pensamentos (o autor introduz aqui a palavra pravrtti, onde Vrtti significa ocupação, tendência, modificação mental e pra signfica para a frente (outward flow que vimos em I.4)
Tudo isto se resuma à ideia de que o oceano de consciência ganha ondas devido à acção de prakrti tal como já tínhamos visto.
Exemplo da acção de prakrti sobre puruna.
Quando a componente de sattvaguna da força prakrti (parte subtil) domina, o oceano calmo de consciência (purusa) adquire o conhecimento de que é consciência ou seja adquire o conhecimento de “Eu”, designamos esta aquisição por mahat ou mahatattva. Tratando-se de um objecto da consciência este é representado por uma onda. A Consciência que inicialmente era pura passou a ter uma impureza.

As três componentes de prakrti estão em constante mudança, após a componente sattvaguna ser dominante e introduzir o conceito de “Eu existo” (Aham gachhami) neste oceano de consciência, esta componente diminui ao mesmo tempo que a componente rajoguna aumenta. Ora uma força prakrti em que esta componente domina cria outra onda no oceano, que neste caso representa o conceito de “autoria”, “eu faço”. E assim o oceano passa a ter duas ondas:
Um oceano com estas duas impurezas não pode ainda actuar pois não há (segundo o autor) nenhum objecto no oceano onde actuar. Esses objectos sobre os quais estas duas ondas actuam citta. Citta ainda não é um objecto da consciência concreto (como por exemplo a cadeira onde estou sentado), mas sim uma “onda bébé” de consciência que ainda não se formou completamente (é isto que entendi da descrição), Citta tem origem na acção da força prakrti cuja componente tamoguna é dominante. É sobre Citta que as duas ondas “Eu” e “Eu faço” actuam para (por intermédio de prakrti uma vez mais onde tamoguna domina) para fazer evoluir esta “onda bébé” para uma onda que represente um objecto concreto da consciência. Citta é também designado por matéria da mente e tem o potencial para se transformar num pensamento.

O universo físico, denso, inanimado é construído pela acção de prakrti forte em tamoguna. A este processo designamos por saincara. Dito de outra forma prakrti aprisiona gradualmente purusa, resultando assim um progressiva ignorância sobre a verdadeira natureza de purusa (a este processo de aprisionamento é também designado por avidyamaya pois avidya = ignorancia) (ver fig 2 de I.4, as setas outward flow - também chamados avaranii shakti - representam este aprisionamento)
Ter na consciência os objectos mahat (“Eu sou”), aham (“Eu faço”) e citta é essencial para que se formem pensamentos, verificamos isto notando por exemplo que o nosso discurso é formado por sujeito, verbo, predicado (objecto)

title: I.3
text:
Comentários:

“Se Deus existe, então mostra-me.” já os ateus gregos diziam aos teístas. A variante desta afirmação abordada neste sutra é Se purusa e prakrti existem, então mostra-me.
A demonstração que o autor sugere-se a apresentar em I.3, não é na realidade uma demonstração; demonstrações só existem na matemática. O que ele realmente faz é aquilo a que chamamos em inglês “inference to the best explanation”.
Eis alguns exemplos de “inference to the best explanation” apresentados pelo autor:

existência de electrões deixa vestígios, esses vestígios levam-nos a inferir que existem electrões;
as pegadas numa floresta são também vestígios que nos levam a inferir que alguma raposa ali passou recentemente;
o LHC deixa dados, que nos levam a inferir que bosão Higgs existe.

Demonstração da existência de purusa requer o seguinte lemma:
A inteligência explica/justifica a existência da capacidade de resposta da matéria a estímulos.
Exemplo: As experiências de Bose com tecidos e metais revelaram que a resposta ao mesmo estímulo era muito semelhante (os detalhes da experiência não os sei…)
Demonstração do lemma:
A resposta mecânica da matéria é descrita em grande detalhe por teoria matemática, ou seja, há uma ordem que descreve tal comportamento estímulo-resposta. Essa ordem existe apenas porque existe previamente uma inteligência.
o autor não define inteligência, simplesmente dá a entender que tudo aquilo que seja capaz de reagir mecânicamente a um estimulo é dotado daquilo a que chama de inteligência, ou seja, a propriedade de inteligência é necessária à capacidade de reagir mecânicamente (ou não mecânicamente) a estímulos externos.



A Demonstração: Tudo no universo (micro e macro) exibe comportamentos estimulo-resposta que são descritos por leis; incluindo as partes do universo que não entendemos (exemplo: caos). Segundo o nosso lemma, tal pressupões que existe inteligência. Como a inteligência pressupõe a existência de consciência, concluímos que consciência universal (aka purusa) existe.
A segunda coisa que o autor pretende demonstrar é a existência de prakrti, mas falo que forma confusa, pois confunde o conceito de força que molda a consciência universal com o resultado dessa força, uma analogia ajuda a entender isto. Prakrti é como a força das mãos do oleiro e o vaso é o resultado final da acção dessa força sobre o barro (consciência). Não faz sentido usar prakrti para nos defenirmos à força e ao vaso também, mas é precisamente isto que o autor faz neste sutram. Usando esta junção de conceitos eis como o autor justifica a existência de prakrti: a realidade física é como o “vaso” e o “vaso” é prakrti.
O autor procura tb demonstrar que purusa e prakrti são inseparáveis. Purusa é aquilo a que os físicos chamam de energia/matéria e os padrões comportamentais da energia/matéria comporta-se de forma ordenada sujeita a forças, essas forças são prakrti.
O autor termina nas ultima duas paginas por descrever a fase evolutiva pratisaincara: a evolução progressiva desde seres vivos unicelulares até ao ser humano ocorre ao mesmo tempo que existe uma libertação progressiva de prakrti e uma revelação progressiva da consciência universal. Mesmo no estádio de ser humano, há diferentes níveis evolutivos de seres humanos, no sentido em que há diferentes níveis de revelação desta consciência universal. De forma grosseira temos:
bacterias < animais/plantas < macacos < ser humano lvl 1 < ser humano lvl 2 < … < buda

title: Examples of Polynomials
text:
Mediatrix Equation
With similar flavor as a line that passes through two point, our goal now is to find the equation of the line that is perpendicular to the line that passes through the point and is equidistant from the two points.
The word equidistant my cause some head scratching, here’s a picture



A blue line that intercepts the two red points and the mediatrix in pink.


For each point \((x,y)\) on the pink line compute the distance from the red points, these two distances must be the same. This is what describes the mediatrix line (in pink).






Recall



The distance, \(d\), between the point \((x_0,y_0)\) and the point \((x,y)\)

is given by the Pythagoras theorem:
\[
d^2 = (x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2
\]


Formally, lets say the red points have coordinates \((x_0,y_0)\) and \((x_1,y_1)\), our function is composed by the points which is equidistant from both, in mathematical notation, the mediatrix line is given by:
\[
\{(x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^2\,\,|\,\, (x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2 = (x-x_1)^2+(y-y_1)^2\}
\tag{14}\]
Lets simplify the element-hood test:
\[
\begin{align}
&(x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2 = (x-x_1)^2+(y-y_1)^2\\
\iff &x^2-2x_0x+x_0^2 + y^2-2y_0y+y_0^2 = x^2-2x_1x+x_1^2 + y^2-2y_1y+y_1^2\\
\iff & 0= 2(y_0-y_1)y + 2(x_0-x_1)x+y_1^2-y_0^2+x_1^2-x_0^2\\
\iff & y = -\frac{x_0-x_1}{y_0-y_1}x +\frac{1}{2}(y_1^2+x_1^2-y_0^2-x_0^2)\\
\iff & y = -\frac{1}{m} x + \frac{1}{2}\Delta^2
\end{align}
\]
where in the last line I lumped terms into the parameters \(m\) and \(\Delta\).
\[
m:=\frac{y_1-y_0}{x_1-x_0}\qquad \Delta^2:=y_1^2+x_1^2-y_0^2-x_0^2
\]
\(m\) is the slope of the line that contains the red points, while \(\Delta^2\) is the difference between the squared-distances of the red points with respect to the origin.
As we can see the second powers in the element-hood test cancel and what remain is the equation \(y = -\frac{1}{m} x + \frac{1}{2}\Delta^2\), which is just a linear combination of \(x\) and \(x^0\) with weights \(-1/m\) and \(\Delta^2/2\), the hallmark of a line equation of the line. We conclude, the set Equation 14 is equal to
\[
\{(x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^2\,\,|\,\, y = -\frac{1}{m} x + \frac{1}{2}\Delta^2\}
\]
Comparing with Equation 4 we identify \(a_1 =-1/m\) and \(a_0=\Delta^2/2\).

title: Angular Momentum in QM
text:
Lets see how knowing the eigenbasis of the angular momentum operators helps us in finding the eigenbasis of an Hamiltonian which commutes with the angular momentum operators.
The system consists in one nitrogen ion \(N^+_2\) found in plasmas. We want to describe the quantum states of its rotation motion, the appropriate Hamiltonian is thus:
\[
H=\frac{L^2}{2I}
\]
where \(I=\frac{1}{2}m d^2\) is the moment of inertia of the molecule, \(m\) is the nitrogen mass, \(d\) is the interatomic distance.
This Hamiltonian commutes with \(L^2\) and \(L_z\) therefore we can find a basis of eigenstates common to the three operators:
\[
\{H,L^2,L_z\}
\]
Knowing the eigenbasis common to \(L^2\) and \(L_z\) facilitates finding the eigenstates of \(H\) as we shall see.
The eigenstates of \(L^2\) and \(L_z\) are:
\[
\begin{align}&L^2\ket{l,m}=l(l+1)\hbar^2\ket{l,m},\\&L_z\ket{l,m}=m\hbar\ket{l,m}.\end{align}
\tag{37}\]
To find the eigenstates of \(H\) we start by representing \(H\) in this basis and then compute the eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
Acting with \(H\) on the basis and using Equation 37 we find: \(H|l,m\rangle = \frac{l(l+1)\hbar^2}{2I}|l,m\rangle\). This is analogous to step zero from 7). Following the same steps we get the entries of the matrix:
\[
\langle l,m|H|l',m'\rangle = \frac{l(l+1)\hbar^2}{2I}\delta_{l,l'}\delta_{m,m'}
\tag{38}\]
which we can use to represent the matrix:

Shown are the \(l=0\) and \(l=1\) subspaces representations, note the matrix is infinite!
Observe that the matrix is diagonal and thus the eigenvectors \(|l,m\rangle\) of \(\{L^2,L_z\}\) are also eigenvectors of \(H\)!! There is no need to diagonalize the matrix blocks.
We should note that the calculation of Equation 38 is essentially unnecessary since we can immediately conclude that the eigenvectors \(|l,m\rangle\) common to \(L^2\) and \(L_z\) are exactly those of \(H\) from the fact that \(H\) is just \(L^2\) times a constant.






Commentary



If the matrix blocks were not diagonal we would have to diagonalize them by the usual linear algebra procedure. In such a case the triple degenerate eigenvectors of \(\mathcal{E}(l=1)\) would be distinguished by a new index \(n\).

title: Example 2
text:
Example 2:
Consider a spin-1/2 particle whose energy eigenstates and eigenvalues are given by \(|n\rangle\) and \(E_n=n^2 E_1\) for \(n=1,2,..\)
Assume we have a system with two of these particles, which do not interact.

Write the ground state and first excited states when the total spin is zero \(S=0\). What are the corresponding eigenvalues?
What is the ground state when the total spin is \(1\)?

Answer:
The single particle states are of the form \(|\text{spacial}\rangle \otimes|\text{spin}\rangle\) where
\[
\begin{align}
&|\text{spacial}\rangle \in \text{span}\{\text{Eigenstates of $h$ }\}\\
&|\text{spin}\rangle \in \text{span}\{\text{Eigenstates of $S^2$ and $S_z$}\}
\end{align}
\]
More concretely we have \(|n\rangle\otimes |m\rangle\) with \(n=1,2,..\) and \(m=\pm1/2\); usually written as \(|n,m\rangle\).
Why are the single particle eigenstates of this form? Answer: The observables \(\{h,S^2,S_z\}\) commutes (common eigenvectors exists) and the operators are independent (\(h\) is not a function of either \(S^2\) or \(S_z\)) and thus it suffices to specify the quantum numbers of each operator (the quantum number \(s=1/2\) is suppressed in the notation)
The possible quantum states of the total system are the eigenstates of the observables \(\{H,S_1^2,S_{1z}, S_2^2,S_{2z} \}\) with the total Hamiltonian as \(H = h_1 +h_2+V_{12}\) where \(V_{12}\) is zero since we are assuming non-interaction particles. We should look at these operators as extensions, for example the Hamiltonian is:
\[
h_1 \otimes 1_2 \otimes 1_{s1} \otimes 1_{s2}+ 1_1 \otimes h_2 \otimes 1_{s1} \otimes 1_{s2}
\]
with
\[ h_i|i:n_i\rangle =n_i^2E_1|i:n_i\rangle \]
The eigenstates of the system are of the form:
\[
|1:n_1,m_1\rangle \otimes |2:n_2,m_2\rangle
\]
which can be written more compactly as:
\[
|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |m_1,m_2\rangle
\]
Hence for \(i=1,2\):
\[
\begin{align}
&H|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |m_1,m_2\rangle = \frac{n_1^2+n_2^2}{2I}E_1|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |m_1,m_2\rangle\\
&S^2_i|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |m_1,m_2\rangle = \frac{3\hbar^2}{4}|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |m_1,m_2\rangle\\
&S_{iz}|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |m_1,m_2\rangle = m_i\hbar |n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |m_1,m_2\rangle
\end{align}
\]
The two question posed refer to the total spin of the system, so it is a good idea to change the spin basis and write the spin part involving the total spin. We know from the previous theory that:
\[
\text{span}\{|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |m_1,m_2\rangle\} = \text{span}\{|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle\}
\]
Where again we suppress from the spin part this: \(|\overbrace{1/2,1/2},S,M\rangle\)
\[
\begin{align}
&H|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle = \frac{n_1^2+n_2^2}{2I}E_1|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle\\
&S^2_i|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle = \frac{3\hbar^2}{4}|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle\\
&S^2|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle = S(S+1)\hbar^2|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle\\
&S_{z}|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle = M\hbar |n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle
\end{align}
\]

We want the states of the form \(|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle\) such that the following statements are true:
\[
\begin{cases}
P_{21}|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle =-1\times|n_1,n_2\rangle \otimes |S,M\rangle\\
|S,M\rangle = |S=0,M=0\rangle\\
\frac{n_1^2+n_2^2}{2I}E_1\quad \text{is minimum}
\end{cases}
\] Since the spin part is antissimetric:
\[
\begin{align}
P_{21} |0,0\rangle &= P_{21} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|1:\uparrow,2:\downarrow\rangle - |1:\downarrow,2:\uparrow\rangle ) \\
&= -1\times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|1:\uparrow,2:\downarrow\rangle - |1:\downarrow,2:\uparrow\rangle )\\
&-1\times |0,0\rangle
\end{align}
\] we seek a spacial ket that is symmetric and whose energy is minimum.
The spacial state \(n_1=n_2=1\) statisfies the criteria. Therefore the final answer is:
\[
|1,1\rangle\otimes|0,0\rangle
\]
or
\[
|1,1\rangle \otimes \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|1:\uparrow,2:\downarrow\rangle - |1:\downarrow,2:\uparrow\rangle )
\]
whose eigenvalue is \((1^2 + 1^2) E_1\).
Following a similar line of reasoning the first excited state with \(S=0\) must be:
\[
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|2,1\rangle + |1,2\rangle) \otimes |0,0\rangle
\]
Observe that the spacial spate is symmetric when we use the \(+\) sign!
When \(S=1\) the spin state is one of the symetric triplet states:
$$
\[\begin{align}
&\ket{1,1}=\ket{1/2,1/2}\\
&\ket{1,0}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(\ket{-\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}}+\ket{\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}}\right)\\
&\ket{1,-1}=\ket{-1/2,-1/2}
\end{align}\] $$
As a result the spacial part must be antissymetric for the whole quantum state of the two particles to be antissymetric as PEP requires. Thus:
\[
\begin{align}
&\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|2,1\rangle - |1,2\rangle)\otimes |1,1\rangle\\
&\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|2,1\rangle - |1,2\rangle)\otimes |1,0\rangle\\
&\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(|2,1\rangle - |1,2\rangle)\otimes |1,-1\rangle\\
\end{align}
\]
Notice the minimum energy AND antissymetry of the spacial part only occurs at the FIRST excited state. The spacial ground state is the symmetric \(|1,1\rangle\).

title: Untitled
text:
Cap 1 - Descrição de brahmacakra
brahmacakra := ciclo criação ou sistema cosmológico
I.1 Brahma é composto por Shiva e Chakti
Para entender este sutram é preciso ter em conta as seguintes ideias do tantra:

os processos que dizemos serem macroscósmicos (não significa externos!) refletem-se de forma microscópica no nosso interior (microcosmos)
Em toda a nossa experiência podemos identificar:

a consciência, que é constante no tempo (imutável)
processos dinâmicos, i.e., processos que evoluem no tempo, como são exemplo os nossos pensamentos, emoções e aquilo que observamos pelos sentidos. Estes processos são também designados por objectos da consciência.

Relação: consciência é necessária aos processos dinâmicos.
Esta relação sugere que [experiênciar um processo dinâmico] é um novo estado de consciência, para entender o quero dizer por estado usemos a seguinte analogia: cada onda é um novo estado de um oceano originalmente calmo (o estado original = calmo, estado final= ondular). Assim os nossos pensamentos, emoções e o que recolhemos dos sentidos existe dentro de um campo de consciência (=cognição) e são novos estados de consciência.
Brahma = conjunto das consciências de todos nós (o que inclui - por definição de consciência - todos objectos da consciência)
Shakti = força que altera o estado calmo do “oceano” de consciência para o estado de “ondas” (objectos da consciência)
pensamento e consciência são coisas distintas, um pensamento é um exemplo de um objecto da consciência, uma onda, e que portanto evolui no tempo.
Materialismo = sistema pensamento (filosófico) que têm como suposição - a matéria é primordial. Tudo o que experenciamos pelos sentidos, a consciência, o pensamento, as emoções etc emergem da matéria. Por exemplo, quando vejo uma rosa, essa experiência emerge do funcionamento do cérebro (matéria). Se o cérebro não existir ou estiver lesionado podemos não ver a cor da rosa ou mesmo a rosa. Donde podemos dizer que o funcionamento do cérebro é necessário à experiência da rosa.
Mas será o cérebro necessário à consciência ou será a consciência necessária ao cérebro?
O autor parece sugerir que a última é que está correcta pois a actividade cerebral não passa de algo que observamos e medimos e portanto trata-se de mais um objecto da consciência (processo dinâmico). Conclui-se daqui que a consciência é primordial (segundo o autor)
atman (alma) = consciência, “eu sou” puro
Sadhana: Toda as definições e ideias acima tornam-se mais claras pela experiência. Observa os teus pensamentos ao longo do dia, eventualmente tornar-se-á claro que a sua dinâmica temporal é observada constantemente pela consciência, esta sim invariante no tempo. A meditação deverá ajudar nesta experiência, pois ao acalmar a dinâmica do oceano, torna-se mais evidente quando é que este deixa de ser calmo.

title: I.4
text:
A consciência suprema, purusottama, é o núcleo do universo.
Comentários:

Tudo no universo (incluindo a nossa mente) pode ser descrito por sistemas e subsistemas. Para identificar um sistema temos de identificar uma fronteira, física ou conceptual, que separa o sistema, de tudo o resto (que em si é outro sistema).
Ao conjunto de sistemas e das leis que os descrevem é aquilo a que autor chama de estrutura do universo (ou da natureza).
Suposição: Um sistema (físico ou conceptual) apresenta sempre um núcleo.
Suposição: o universo tem origem inteligente.
Isto tem um implicação muito importante, pois se é inteligente, é que esperar que exista uma estrutura sob todo o universo.
Suposição: O universo - oceano com ondas - evolui ao longo do tempo devido à força Chakti. O estado dessas ondas reflecte as características da força que as originou, essas características são três, as três gunas. Cada onda reflecte assim uma certa combinação de três gunas. Portanto, cada onda é distinguível das demais e dizemos por isso que existe um principio de dualidade, entenda-se, um principio de que os objectos da consciências (ondas) são distinguíveis. O autor refere-se que há uma “Lei de Dualidade” a actuar sobre o universo (criação), o que se entende por isto é que existe um força (chakti) que consegue formar ondas (conceptuais ou físicas) que nós conseguimos distinguir.
Suposição: A nossa mente apenas consegue entender as partes do universo (conceptual ou físico) que têm estrutura, i.e., que resultam da actuação da Lei de Dualidade. Mais ainda, também apenas entendemos as partes que têm um centro.
O que é esta ideia de centro?
A seguinte figura dá-nos a ideia:

Um sistema de conceitos ou físico tem sempre uma estrutura que se assemelha a esta figura. Os pontos representam ideias ou sistemas físicos, enquanto os ramos representam uma certa relação entre ambos.
Exemplos:

O centro de uma história é o moral da história.
A terra gira em torno do sol, o centro é o sol.
A família é o centro das nossas relações sociais.
Os pensamentos e emoções que temos têm uma estrutura centrada na nossa memória (karma), o seu centro.
uma pintura (quadro) tem o seu centro também, que tanto pode ser explicito ou implicito (conceptual)

Todos os sistemas que conseguimos identificar fazem parte de um Mega Sistema a que chamamos de:

sistema supremo
sistema cosmológico
brahmacakra (AM)

A evolução temporal do sistema cosmológico é de tal forma que satisfaz uma alternância (ciclica) entre saincara e pratisaincara.
O ponto fixo da dinâmica do sistema é o mar de consciência testemunhal a que o autor chama também paramashiva, purusottama, consciência nuclear.
O autor refere também que o universo físico não tem centro físico, mas tem um centro conceptual, que é o individuo (jiivatma). Esta ideia é um pouco confusa porque o individuo, que entendo como sendo o corpo físico, muda no tempo e portanto não está fixo.
O autor introduz vários tipos de consciência, que na verdade são apenas rótulos úteis para distinguir diferentes pontos vista sobre a Consciência (aka oceano de Consciência) que é único. Assim no texto encontramos:

consciência refere-se à definição intuitiva de consciência (não a um oceano).
Consciência testemunhal é imutável e “observa” os objectos da consciência. É também designada por paramashiva ou purusottama
Consciência nuclear refere-se à parte do oceano que é imutável. Por isso esta designação é equivalente à Consciência testemunhal.
Consciência Suprema é equivalente a Consciência, o que por sua vez se refere à [Consciência testemunhal] + [objectos da consciência].
objectos da consciência são a parte mutável da Consciência (as ondas).

title: Polynomial division
pol_division
text:
Example 1: \(22 /3\) using basic principles
Consider the numbers \(p=22\) and \(d=3\), the division \(22\) by \(3\) means
\[ 22=7\cdot 3 +1 \]
This formula relates the numbers \(22\) and \(3\). It breaks the large number \(22\) into a sum of two terms \(7\cdot 3\) and \(1\), the first is divisible by \(3\) the other is not.
To computing \(22/3\) is equivalent to find \(q\) and \(r\) such that:
\[
22=q\cdot 3+r \qquad 0\leq r<3
\tag{5}\]
How would we try to solve this equation?
Answer: We guess the \(q\) and \(r\). To help us guide our guesses, lets unpack what the symbol \(22\) means:
\[
22 = 2 \cdot 10^1 + 2 \cdot 10^0 = 2\cdot 10 +2
\]
Inspired by this result we try match the \(q\cdot 3\) term with the \(2\cdot 10\) term, hence we try to guess \(q\) so that \(q\cdot 3\) is as close as possible to \(2\cdot 10\). Here are some guesses we might have made:

Guess 1: \(q=6\) because \(6\cdot 3=18\) which is close to \(2\cdot 10=20\)
Substituting into Equation 5 we find \(22=6\cdot 3+r\) , the value of \(r\) for this \(q\) is then given by \(r=22-18=4\).
\[
22 =6\cdot 3+4
\tag{6}\]
Since the remainder \(4\) is not between \(0\) and \(3\), we are not in the conditions of our theorem, see ?@eq-eq_of_the_thm, and is thus divisible by \(3\) this suggests we can break \(4\) into a sum \(q'\cdot 3\) which is divisible by \(3\) and a term \(r'\) which is not divisble by :

\[
4 = q'\cdot 3 + r' \qquad 0\leq r' < 3
\tag{7}\] task now is to solve this equation for \(q'\) and \(r'\). Guessing the answer we find \(q'=1\) and as a result \(r'=4-1\cdot 3=1\) and thus
\[
4 = 1\times 3 +1
\tag{8}\]
Combining the results Equation 6 and Equation 8 we find:
\[
22 = 6\times 3 + 1\times 3 +1
\]
Simplifying we get the division of \(22\) where the \(q=7\) is as large as possible and the \(r=1\) is small as possible:
\[
22 = 7\times 3 +1
\]
Guess 2: \(q=7\) because \(7\cdot 3=21\) is above \(2\cdot 10\) but close.
Substituting we obtain:
\[
22 = 7\times 3 + r
\]
which is equivalent to
\[
r = 22-21 = 1
\]
Our remainder \(r\) is smaller than \(3\), no further division of \(r\) by \(3\) is needed, we conclude again that
\[
22 = 7\times 3 +1
\]
Guess 3: \(q=8\) gives \(8\cdot 3=24\) which is again close to \(2\cdot 10\), though not so much as the previous guess. Substituting we find:
\[
22 = 8\times 3 + r \iff r=22-24 =-2
\]
Thus:
\[
22 = 8\times 3 -2
\]
The remainder is not positive as required in ?@eq-eq_of_the_thm, we make it positive by adding \(0=3-3\)
\[
22 = 8\times 3 -2 +3-3 = (8-1)\times 3 +(3-2) = 7\times 3 +1
\]
Which simplifies into the result we already know:
\[
22=7\times 3 +1
\]







Commentary



The decomposition of \(22=2\cdot 10 +2\) is useful but not mandatory. We could had decomposed in other useful ways, useful means, useful to give us an hint into what the number \(q\) might be.
For example \(22=18+4\) is a good decomposition, because it suggests a guess of \(q=6\) (observe \(6\cdot 3=18\)), the natural guess would follow as Guess 1.

title: pol_division
section: Example 2: \(22/3\) using elementary school’s long division
text:
Example 2: \(22/3\) using elementary school’s long division

The elementary school reasoning is as follows:

The closest multiple of \(3\) which is close to \(20\) is \(7\).
Since \(7\times 3 = 21\), subtracting \(22-21\) gives us \(1\).
Since \(1\) is not divisible by \(3\), which means it is between \(0\) and \(3\), this is the remainder of the calculation.

Observe it is analogous to the \(q=7\) guess’s approach we seen above.
In conclusion the elementary long division is based on the decomposition of \(p\) into powers of \(10\) and subsequent guess of \(q\) which yields \(q\cdot d\) closest to the (current) higher power of \(10\) in \(p\) (we do that because we want \(q\cdot d\) to cover the highest power with a small error).

title: pol_division
section: Example 3: \(1001/12\) using elementary school’s long division
text:
Example 3: \(1001/12\) using elementary school’s long division
To complement and expand on the previous example, let us consider now a more sophisticated division \(1001/12\), how do we argue as in elementary school?
We observe the number \(1001\) we lump digits from left to right and ask whether the lumped is larger (and thus divisible) than \(12\):

The first lump is just the digit \(1\) on the left in \(1001\), it is smaller than \(12\) and thus not divisible.
What does this line of reasoning means? Focusing on the first digit and checking whether it is divisible by \(12\) is equivalent to decompose \(1001\) as \(1001 = 1\cdot 10^3 +1\) and trying to guess what \(q\) that makes \(q\cdot 12\) best cover the \(1\cdot 10^3\) on the lhs of:
\[
1\cdot 10^3 +1 = q\cdot 12+r
\]
Instead of trying to solve this problem the elementary school algorithm, tell us, instead, to lumps the first two digits of \(1001\), and try again: [Is \(10\) divisible by \(12\)?].
The second lump is \(10\). Once again we see \(10\) is not divisible by \(12\) seince \(10<12\).
What does this line of reasoning mean? Lumping the first two digits on the left trying to divide by \(12\) is equivalento to trying to solve the equation:
\[
10\cdot 10^2 +1 = q\cdot 12+r
\]
Notice that we could do it, a good guess would be \(q=10^2\) again, but we do not follow this path, as stated by the elementary’s school algorithm we should instead lump the three digits on the left and try again by asking [Is \(100\) divisible by \(12\)?].
The third lump is \(100\). Yes! Since \(100>12\), we finally have a lump which we can divide by \(12\). How many times \(12\) fits in \(100\)? After some thought and side calculations we arrive at the answer \(8\).





What does this line of reasoning mean? The question implicit in this step of the elementary school’s algorithm is: Can you find \(q\) and \(r\) such that:
\[
100 \cdot 10 +1 = q\cdot 12 +r
\tag{10}\]
Yes we can, guessing \(q=8\cdot10\) we can easily make \(q\cdot 12\) cover the largest term \(100\cdot 10\) on the lhs of ?@eq-100_10_1 . In case the \(8\cdot 10\) guess is not clear, note that \(12\) fits \(8\) times in \(100\), but since what we actually have is \(100\cdot 10\) we have to multiply the \(8\) by \(10\) giving us the \(q=8\cdot 10\). The fact that \(8\) comes multiplied by \(10\) is the reason why we put in the ten’s place (under the \(1\) in \(12\)):






The next step in ESA is to multiply \(8\times 12 = 96\) and place it under the ten’s place of \(1001\),
What does this step mean? Because, \(8\) is under the ten’s place, we should see it as \(8\cdot 10\) and not just an \(8\), thus this step is doing the calculation \(8\times 10 \times 12 =960\), rewriting the \(960\) as a \(96\cdot 10\) tell us we should put a \(96\) in the ten’s place under the \(1001\) .





Next in ESA is to compute the difference \(100-96=4\) and then drop the rightmost \(1\) in \(1001\):
What does this step mean?
This step is the computation of the remainder of Equation 10 for our first guess \(q=8\cdot 10\):
\[ \begin{align} &100\times 10 +1 = 8\cdot 10\cdot 12 +r\\ \implies &r= (100-96)\times 10+1\\
\implies & r=4\times 10 +1 \end{align}  \tag{11}\]





Since the remainder \(r=41\) does not satisfy \(0\leq r<12\), is not the smallest it can be, i.e., \(12\) still fits in it a few number of times, the ESA does not stop here - inside the problem we are attempting to solve \(1001/12\) we found a sub-problem, which is now to divide \(41\) by \(12\). How many times is \(12\) in \(41\)?
Just like we lumped digits from the left in \(1001\) and did check whether they are or not divisible by \(12\), we now do the same with \(41\): The first lump is just \(4\), which is not divisible by \(12\), so we lump the first two digits giving us \(41\). Trial and error and guess-work tell us that \(12\) fits \(3\) times in \(41\), we place it under the one’s place (under the \(2\) in \(12\)):





What does this step means? The sub-problem we are trying to solve is: find \(q'\) and \(r'\) such that:
\[
41 = q'\cdot 12 +r'
\]
By simple guess-work, \(q'=3\) is a good answer because it guarantees \(q'\cdot 12\) is the largest number below \(41\). Note this \(3\) from our guess is \(3\times 1\) (and not \(3\cdot 10\)), thus we place it under the one’s place of \(12\).
The next step in ESA is to multiply \(3\times 12\) to obtain \(36\), we write it under the \(1\)’s place of \(41\):





Removing from the current remainder \(41\) this \(36\) gives:





What does this step mean? Using equation notation the problem being solved is:
\[
\begin{align}
&41 = 3\cdot 12 +r'\\
\implies &r' = 41-36 =5
\end{align}
\tag{12}\]
Combining our results Equation 11 and Equation 12 we conclude:
\[
\begin{cases}
1001 = 8\times 10\times 12 + 41\\
41 = 3\cdot 12 +5
\end{cases}
\]





See Example.

title: pol_division
text:
Example 4: \(1001/12\) using basic principles (A)
What is the solution \(q\) and \(r\) of the equation:
\[
1001 = q \times 12 + r \qquad 0\leq r<12
\]
There are many paths and we follow then in stages.
The simplest path is to immediately guess the answer, one step. You would have to guess \(q=83\) and \(r=5\).
Depending on the quality of our guesses we increase the number of steps.
Lets decompose \(1001\) into powers of \(10\) to aid our guesses (other decomposition are possible, the powers of \(10\) is the basic one because it is exactly what the symbol \(1001\) means)
\[
1001 = 1\cdot 10^3+0\cdot 10^2 +0\cdot 10^1+1\cdot 10^0 = 1\cdot 10^3 +1\cdot 10^0
\]
Lets guess the solution for:
\[
1\cdot 10^3 +1 = q\cdot(10+2)+r
\]
Guess: \(q=8\cdot 10\) guarantees that \(q\cdot 10\) is close to \(1\cdot 10^3\) (notice \(8\) is almost \(10\))
Substitution gives:
\[
\begin{align}
&1\cdot 10^3 +1 = 8\cdot 10^2 +16 \cdot 10 + r\\
\implies&1\cdot 10^3 +1 = 9\cdot10^2+6\cdot10+r\\
\implies & r=1\cdot 10^2-6\cdot 10+1 \\
\implies&r=4\cdot10+1
\end{align}
\]
The remainder is positive and larger than the divisor \(12\) so we keep going.






Commentary



Note that a guesses \(q=9\cdot 10\) or \(q=10^2\) would lead to a negative remainders. These two guesses would be fine since we only need the final remainder to be positive, not the intermediate ones. Our choice of \(q=8\) is motivated by convenience.


We have to solve:
\[
4\cdot 10+1 = q'\cdot(10+2)+r'
\]
Guess’: \(q'=3\)
Substitute:
\[
\begin{align}
&4\cdot 10+1 = 3\cdot 10 + 6 + r'\\
\implies &r'=1\cdot 10-6+1 = 4+1=5
\end{align}
\]
We conclude that:
\[
1001=(8\cdot 10+3)\cdot 12+5
\]
which simplifies into:
\[
1001=83\cdot 12+5
\]
EXERCISE: Make your initial guess \(q=10^3\) and arrive at this result.
SOLUTION:
In this solution we present the steps to solve the problem in two parallel ways: using guesswork to solve the equations and the table-like approach (see the pictures).
The basic problem at hand can be presented in the following fashion:

Guess: \(q=10^2\) so that \(q\cdot (10+2)\) has a \(10^3\) term to cancel the \(1\cdot 10^3\) from \(1001\).
This basic step can be presented as:

Substituting we find:
\[ \begin{align} &1\cdot 10^3 + 1 = 10^2(10+2)+r\\ \implies & r=-2\cdot 10^2+1 \end{align} \]
Which is represented by:

The current remainder is negative but is still divisible by \(12\) (given it is larger than \(12\)):
\[ -2\cdot 10^2+1 = q''\cdot (10+2) +r'' \]
Guess’: \(q' = -2\cdot 10\) so that the \(-2\cdot 10^2\) is canceled on the lhs.
This guess step can be represented as:

Substitute:
\[ \begin{align} &-2\cdot 10^2 +1 = -2\cdot 10^2 -4\cdot 10 +r'\\ \implies & r' = 4\cdot 10 +1 \end{align} \]
Presented as:

Since the remainder \(4\cdot 10+1\) is divisible by \(12\) we write:
\[ 4\cdot 10 +1 = q''\cdot (10+2)+r'' \]
which leads to our next guess.
Guess’’: \(q''=4\) to cancel the lhs \(4\cdot 10\)
Substitution:
\[ \begin{align} &4\cdot 10 +1 =4\cdot 10+8 + r''\\ \implies& r'' = -7 \end{align} \]
Show in:

Collecting terms:
\[ 1001=(10^2-2\cdot 10+4)\cdot 12 -7 \]
Our remainder in negative, hence add \(0=12-12\) to the rhs:
\[ 1001=(10^2-2\cdot 10+4-1)\cdot 12+(12-7) \]
In conclusion:
\[ 1001=83\cdot 12 +5 \]

title: pol_division
text:
Example 4: \(1001/12\) using basic principles (B)
Another useful decomposition is:
\[
1001=600+401
\]
How would we argue in this case?
Guess 1:
Observing that \(1001=600+401\) and \(5\times 12 =60\) we guess that actual solution \(q\) is close to \(10\times 5\):
\[
600+401 = \overbrace{10 \times 5}^{q} \times 12 +r
\]
with the remainder \(r=401\). Since it is not between \(0\) and \(12\) we can do better. Lets break \(401\) by guessing what is \(q'\) and \(r'\) such that:
\[
401 = q'\times 12 + r' \qquad 0\leq r'<12
\]
We think \(q'=3\times10\) is a good solution since \(q'\times 12 = 360\), as a result the remainder is \(r'=401-360=41\)
Not ideal, we want it at most \(12\). Therefore we again break into pieces:
\[
41 = q''\times 12 + r'' \qquad 0\leq r''<12
\]
With the guess \(q''=3\) and the current remainder is just \(r''=41-36=5\).
Note, finally!! We have a remainder smaller than \(12\).
Collecting out calculations we have:
\[
1001 = \overbrace{(10 \times 5 + 3\times 10 + 3)}^{q=83}\times 12 + 5
\]






Commentary



Breaking \(p\) into powers of then has proven to be useful to give us clues about what values of \(q\) to guess. Another strategy is to break \(q\) (in the example above \(p=1001\)) into a large and a smaller part.
\[
p=[\text{large part}]+[\text{small part}]
\]
And then guess the best you can the \(q\) that cancels the large part.
For example \(1001=100\cdot 10+1\) where the large part is \(100\cdot10\), additionally \(100\) is divisible by \(12\) since its larger.
There are many ways to break \(p\), experience will tell you what is ideal or not.

title: pol_division
text:
Example 6: \(1001/12\) using indeterminate coefficients method
A general strategy to solve the problem:
\[
1001=q\cdot 12 +r\qquad 0\leq q<12
\tag{14}\]
starts by splitting the parameters of the equation into powers of \(10\)
\[
\begin{split}&1001=1\cdot 10^3+0\cdot 10^2+0\cdot 10^1+1\cdot 10^0\\&12=1\cdot 10^1+2\cdot 10^0\\\end{split}
\]
and the unknowns \(q\) and \(r\) as well:
\[
\begin{split}&q=a\cdot 10^2+b\cdot 10^2+c\cdot 10^0\\&r=\alpha \cdot 10^0\end{split}
\]
for some real numbers \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) and \(\alpha\). Note that \(q\) must be at most a power \(10^2\) to guarantee a \(10^3\) of \(1001\), meanwhile the remainder \(r\) which must be between \(0\) and \(12\) has to be a number proportional to \(10^0=1\).
Substituting we find
\[
1\cdot 10^3+0\cdot 10^2+0\cdot 10^1+1\cdot 10^0=(a\cdot 10^2+b\cdot 10^1+c\cdot 10^0)\cdot (1\cdot 10^1+2\cdot 10^0) +\alpha \cdot 10^0
\]
Rearranging, we factor the same powers on the right side, which gives us:
\[
1\cdot 10^3+0\cdot 10^2+0\cdot 10^1+1\cdot 10^0=a\cdot 10^3+(2a+b)\cdot 10^2+(2b+c)\cdot 10^1+(2c+\alpha)\cdot 10^0
\tag{15}\]
The goal of determining what is \(q\) and \(r\) that satisfy the conditions Equation 14 becomes the goal of determining \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) and \(\alpha\) that satisfy Equation 15.
Both sides of Equation 15 are equal provides the coefficients of the same powers of \(10\) are equal, that yields the following system of equations to solve:
\[
\begin{cases}10^3:\,\,\,1=a\\10^2:\,\,\,0=2a+b\\10^1:\,\,\,0=2b+c\\10^0:\,\,\,1=2c+\alpha\end{cases}
\]
with the additional constraint \(0\leq \alpha <12\).
The solution of this system of equations is \(a=1\), \(b=-2\), \(c=4\) and \(\alpha=-7\) . Thus:
\[
\begin{split}&q=1\cdot 10^2-2\cdot 10^1+4\cdot 10^0=84\\&r=-7\cdot 10^0=-7\end{split}
\]
Hence, \(1001=84\cdot 12-7\), observe the remainder is negative, therefore we modify the aesthetics of this result in order to make it positive and below \(12\). Adding \(0=12-12\) to the right hand side we find:
\[
\begin{split}&1001=84\cdot 12-7+12-12\\\implies&1001=83\cdot 12+5\end{split}
\]
The final result is \(1001=83\cdot 12+5\) as we computed through other methods.

title: Polynomial division
section: Using the guessing strategy to find a solution
text:
Using the guessing strategy to find a solution
As usual we guess what \(q(x)\) might be and then compute the corresponding remainder \(r(x)\). By checking the constraint \(0\leq \deg r<1\) at each stage of the guessing process, we decide whether to terminate it or keep going. Let us see this in practice:

Guess: \(q(x)=x^2\)
Substituting to compute the remainder of the current guess:
\[
\begin{align}
&x^3+1=x^2\times(x+2)+r(x)\\
\implies &r(x) = -2x^2+1
\end{align}
\]
Since \(\deg (-2x^2+1)=2>\deg(x+1)=1\) we have to keep going, since the remainder is divisible by \(x+2\), the division \((-2x^2+1)/(x+2)\) initiates the prime stage of guessing, hence write:
\[
-2x^2+1 = q'(x)(x+2)+r'(x)
\tag{25}\]
Guess’: \(q'(x)=-2x\)
Substituting the guess into Equation 25 to get the corresponding prime remainder:
\[
\begin{align}
&-2x^2 +1 =-2x(x+2)+r'(x)\\
\implies &r'(x) = 4x+1
\end{align}
\]
Again, the degree of the current remainder is still not zero, so the prime remainder is divisible by \(x+2\), this initiates the double prime stage:
\[
4x+1 = q''(x)(x+2)+r''(x)
\]
Guess’’: \(q''(x)=4\)
Substituting and the corresponding double prime remainder is:
\[
\begin{align}
&4x+1 = 4(x+2)+r''(x)\\
\implies & r''(x)=-7
\end{align}
\]
Finally we arrive at \(\deg(-7)=0\) as we needed by the condition \(0\leq\deg r < 1\), the process end here.
Collect all previous calculations we arrive at the result of our division:
\[
\begin{align}
x^3+1&=\overbrace{x^2}^{q(x)}\times(x+2)+\overbrace{(-2x^2+1)}^{r(x)}\\
&=\overbrace{x^2}^{q(x)}\times (x+2) + \overbrace{(-2x)}^{q'(x)}(x+2) +\overbrace{(4x+1)}^{r'(x)}\\
&=\overbrace{x^2}^{q(x)}\times (x+2) + \overbrace{(-2x)}^{q'(x)}(x+2)+\overbrace{(+4)}^{q''(x)}(x+2) +\overbrace{(-7)}^{r''(x)}\\
&=(x^2-2x+4)(x+2)-7
\end{align}
\]

We conclude that:
\[
x^3+1 = (x^2-2x+4)(x+2)-7
\]

title: Polynomial division
text:
Method of undetermined coefficients
Here we present our problem by casting it as a system of equations to solve. Some students might prefer this approach.
Comparing the lhs and rhs of Equation 24 we notice:

the polynomial \(q(x)\) must have a degree equal to \(2\)
the degree of \(r(x)\) is \(0\)

From this we know the general from of these polynomials to be:
\[
\begin{split}&q(x) :=  ax^2+bx+c\\&r(x) :=  \alpha \end{split}
\]
Substituting we find:
\[
x^3+1=(ax^2+bx+c)(x+2)+\alpha
\]
Expanding the rhs and lumping the same powers of \(x\) we get:
\[
x^3+1=a x^3+(2a+b) x^2+ (2b +c)x^1+(2c+\alpha)
\]
The polynomial on the right is equal to the the left if the coefficients of the same powers are the same, i.e., they satisfy the following system of equations
\[
\begin{cases}x^3:\,\,\,1=a\\x^2:\,\,\,0=2a+b\\x^1:\,\,\,0=2b+c\\x^0:\,\,\,1=2c+\alpha\end{cases}
\]
The solution is \(a=1\), \(b=-2\), \(c=4\) and \(\alpha=-7\):
\[
x^3+1=(x^2-2x+4)(x+2)-7
\]
The similarities between the division of integers and polynomials should be obvious, since we just replace the powers of \(10\) by powers of \(x\).

title: pol_division
text:
A harder strategy
If you want to complicate things here is another way based on arithmetic manipulation. The goal is to compute to compute \(q(x)\) and \(r(x)\), (provided \(x\) is not \(-2\) since \(x+2\) is in the denominator):
\[
\frac{x^3+1}{x+2}=q(x)+\frac{r(x)}{x+2}
\tag{15}\]
We can focus our attention on the left side of the equation and attempt, through trial and error, to manipulate the numerator \(x^3+1\) so that it becomes equal to the denominator \(x+2\). There are many ways to do it, here is one:
\[
\begin{split}\frac{x^3+1}{x+2}&=\frac{\mathbf{x^2}(x+\mathbf{2})\mathbf{-2x^2}+1}{x+2}\\&=x^2+\frac{-2x^2+1}{x+2}\\&=x^2+\frac{\mathbf{-2x}(x+\mathbf{2})+\mathbf{4x}+1}{x+2}\\&=x^2-2x+\frac{4x+1}{x+2}\\&=x^2-2x+\frac{4x+1+\mathbf{8-8}}{x+2}\\&=x^2-2x+\frac{4x+8-7}{x+2}\\&=x^2-2x+4+\frac{-7}{x+2}\end{split} \tag{16}\]
In the first line of Equation 16 we introduced \(0=2x^2-2x^2\) and factored factored \(x^2\) giving us \(\mathbf{x^2}(x+\mathbf{2})\mathbf{-2x^2}+1\). We then cancelled the factors \(x+2\) in the numerator and denominator leaving us with \((-2x^2+1)/(x+2)\) in the second line; now we repeat the the same strategy and try to manipulate this numerator so that \(x+2\) appears again, we do in the third line by introducing \(0=4x-4x\) and factoring \(\mathbf{-2x}\), cancel the \(x+2\) we obtain the result in the fourth line. On the fifth line we added \(0=8-8\) with the goal of again making \(x+2\) appear in the numerator; the sixth line has \(4x+8-7=4(x+2)-7\), where again we cancel with the denominator giving us the final result in the seventh line. % %Here another possible manipulation of the numerator:
Hence we conclude that:
\[
\begin{cases}q(x) :=  x^2-2x+4\\r(x)=-7\end{cases}
\]

title: collision theory intro
text:
Two particles which the only relevant interaction is local when compared with interaction at long range, long range interaction is weak enough that the particles move with constant velocity. When these particles get close enough their straight line trajectories are changed, to this process we call a collision process. (See Sec. 10.6 Greg) In general collisions can give rise to chemical reactions and thus new particles described in general by: \[A_1+A_2\longrightarrow B_1 +B_2+B_3\]We will not deal with these types of reactions but of reactions where the identity of each particle is preserved, we call these scattering reactions. Schematically we have: \[A_1+A_2\longrightarrow A_1+A_2\]An interactions is elastic if none of internal degrees of freedom of the participants is changed during the process. (Cohen Chap VIII A-1) The analysis of the collision process between two particles can be done exactly, by computing the trajectory of both particles from the initial conditions and using Newtons Laws. This can be done in any reference frame in particular either the Lab frame or the CM frame. We’ll discuss both. We can also describe the collision process with statistics, where we attach a probability law to the final velocity vectors given initial ones. We want to focus in these notes on the connection between the rigorous approach and the statistics one.
\[\text{CM}\longrightarrow \text{Col. Cross section}\longrightarrow \text{Prob Law}\longrightarrow \text{averages}\] The collision cross section is an intermediary quantity that occurs in the probability law (function composition)

title: collision theory intro
section: Using Binomial to describe a collision
text:
Using Binomial to describe a collision
When a particle \(A_1\) moves toward \(A_2\) either it collides or not depending on the parameters \(b\) and \(\sigma\). Since I do not know \(b\), neither I know the nature of the interaction process, let us fill the vacuum with assumptions on what is going on. We can either make assumptions on the nature of the one interaction between two particles and then derive the resulting trajectory. Or I could make assumption on what I think would happen if the scattering process is repeated many times or instead I could make assumption on the process on scattering of one \(A_1\) and many \(A_2\). For the latter assume \(A_2\) particles are uniformly distributed in space. If \(N_1\) particles where send one by one (or at once) toward \(N_2\) particles, the \(A_1\) particle would see a density \(n_2\).

and for each \(A_1\) incoming we would have a Bernoulli trial with probability: \[p(\text{hit one $A_2$})=\frac{N_2 \sigma}{A}=n_2\sigma\]Note that the cross section \(\sigma\) describes only whether a particle \(A_2\) is hit or not, and does not care about the direction of the scattered \(A_1\). Later we’ll define a new quantity the scattering cross section which also takes into account this direction.
As a result we have the Binomial probability law on the random variable \(X=[x \,\,\text{particles hit}]\): \[P(X=x)=\binom{N_1}{x}p^x(1-p)^{N_1-x} \] The expected value of this r.v. is: \[E[X]=N_1 p = N_1 n_2 \sigma\] which we rename as \(N_{sc}\) just as Taylor does in formula (14.2) of Chap. 14, also we rename \(N_{inc}:=N_1\), \(n_{tar} :=n_2\):
\[
N_{sc}= N_{inc}n_{tar} \sigma
\tag{13}\]
A schematic situation is shown in the following picture

This diagram is a sequence of \(N\) Bernoulli trials which are in turn characterized by the parameter \(p\), to the attached the Binomial probability law. Mathematically the diagram shows a sequence of trials which can succeed or not. Physically each trial can be interpreted as we want, the probability law is the same formula. For example, each branch can be seen as a trial for hit or miss of \(N=3\) incoming particles toward a uniformly distributed set of target particles which yield a probability of hit given by \(n_2\sigma\). Another example is consider just one incoming particle toward the targets and each trial describes an encounter which can result in a hit or miss. Either way the Bernoulli formula remains exactly the same.






Commentary



The two examples focus on a vertical and horizontal slices of an ensemble. In the horizontal slice view, we have one incoming particle and \(N_1\) trials (for \(t\) seconds) with probability of hit given by \(p\). In this case \(P(X=x)\) should be interpreted as the probability of the same molecule collide \(x\) times in \(N\) trials. In particular \(P(X=1)\) is the probability that one particle collides just once in \(N_1\) trials. \(P(X=1)\) does NOT mean the probability that one particle survives \(N_1-1\) times and then collides at the \(N_1\) trial, this probability would be given by \(p(1-p)^{N_1-1}\) just as written in p. 466 of Reif.

title: collision theory intro
section: Using Poisson distribution to describe collisions
text:
Using Poisson distribution to describe collisions
If we assume we send each one of \(N_1\) particles each \(dt\) seconds (i.e. this is just a way to guarantee each incoming particle does not interact with each other) and make \(N_1\) larger and larger while \(p\) is fixed, the Bernoulli distribution formula is the same as above, but the expected value gets also larger and larger; this is one way to compute the limit distribution, lets see another, more useful one. Take the limit of \(N_1\) while keeping the average value constant instead. Pictorially we have:



A particle is sent each dt seconds, either it hits or misses the array of targets. In t seconds it is sent N=infinity particles.


Define now the r.v. \(X=x \,\,\text{particles hit in $t$ seconds}\), then using the Binomial prob law we find: \[P(X=x)=\binom{N_1}{x}p^x\left(1-p\right)^{N_1-x}\] The expected value is \(E[X]= p N_1\). We would like to take now \(N_1\rightarrow \infty\), but this entails the expected value to go to infinity if we assume \(p\) constant. For the present scenario a better model is to assume the expected value is constant, i.e., we expect in any \(t\) seconds to find on average the same number of hits. To fix the expected value lets rename it as the product \(w t\). Hence let us introduce the quantity \(w\) such that: \[w t\coloneqq N_1 p =N_1 dt\, w\] As a consequence of fixing the average value though the fix of \(w\) we find as a side effect: \[p(\text{hit between $t$ and $t+dt$})\coloneqq w dt =\frac{n_2\sigma}{t}dt\] We see now that \(w\) is the probability of hit per unit time. And \(dt=t/N_1\). As a result the probability law is given by \[P(X=x)=\binom{N_1}{x}\left(\frac{w t}{N_1}\right)^x\left(1-\frac{w t}{N_1}\right)^{N_1-x}\] The expected value is fix at \(E[X]= p N_1=w t\) in this limit.






Commentary



_We need not define the expected value as \(wt\), we could have just defined instead \(E[X]\coloneqq \lambda\) and fix \(\lambda\), this is done in Sec. 3.8 of Wackerly. Setting it to \(wt\) was just a psychologically convenient way to make the parameter \(t\) appear in the equation. Note the Poisson distribution depends on \(wt\) and not on \(t\) or \(w\) alone.


Having established all parameters and their dependencies and what is constant, we only have one independent variable in the probability law. Taking the limit as \(N_1\) goes to infinity we arrive at: \[P(X=x)=\frac{(w t)^x}{x!}e^{-w t}\] Which is the Poisson distribution. But what does it mean? Going back to the diagram above, we have an infinite number of trials between \(0\) and \(t\) seconds with a small probability \(p\), we can interpret them by imagining a set of infinite particles incoming to an uniformly distributed set of target particles each branch the correspond to the trial of a given particle; note how this interpretation is not good, because we would guess that the probability for each hit or miss is finite and not the small number \(n_2\sigma dt/t\). Let us consider a second interpretation, one particle incoming toward the targets and at each trial (which occurs in \(dt\) seconds) decides whether it hit or miss, with probability that must ensure the macroscopic observed value of \(wt\) hits in \(t\) seconds. Under this last interpretation, \(P(X=0)\) is \(e^{-w t}\) is the probability of that particle suffering no collisions in \(t\) seconds at the collision rate \(w\). \(P(X=1)=wt e^{-w t}\) is the probability that the one incoming particle to collide once in \(t\) seconds, but it takes into account, see \(wt\) (represented by the binomial coefficient in Bernoulli) the fact that the collision can occur at any time during those \(t\) seconds.
Notice that \(P(X=1)\) does NOT mean it survives every trial between \(0\) and \(t\) and then collides. That quantity is computed in p. 466 and 467 of Reif. and here is the gist of it, fixing the particular branch described by \[\overbrace{tt\dots tth}^N\]where t=miss and h= hit. We know that it has probability \((1-p)^{N-1}p\) of occurring (it is the [[Bernoulli process#^b9ae87|Geometric distribution]]), we are not interested in any other sequence of hits and misses other than \(tt \dots h\), hence we did not take into account the \(\binom{N}{1}\) factor, substituting \(p=w\,dt\): \[P(\text{survives for $N-1$ trials and then hit})=\left(1-w\,dt\right)^{N-1}w\, dt=\left(1-\frac{wt}{N}\right)^{N-1}w \frac{t}{N}\] this probability law (for this fixed branch) only depends on \(t\) and \(N\), but taking the limit of \(N\longrightarrow \infty\) while \(w\) is constant we get \[P(\text{survives for $t$ seconds and then hit})=e^{-wt}w\,dt\] which depends only on \(t\); this is the [[Bernoulli Process vs Poisson Process|Exponential Distribution]] its the one derived by Reif. in Sec. 12.1. The expected value of r.v. \(t\) is: \[E[t]=\int_0^\infty dt\,e^{wt}w t=\frac{1}{w}\] which is also the characteristic decay of the probability law.

title: collision theory intro
section: Center of Mass Position and Relative Position
text:
Center of Mass Position and Relative Position
The center of mass is given by the following formula:
\[
\mathbf{R} = \frac{m_1 }{M}\mathbf{r}_1 +\frac{m_2 }{M}\mathbf{r}_2\qquad M=m_1+m_2
\tag{1}\]
a linear combination of the current positions weighted by the relative mass.
While the relative position, as the name suggests is just:
\[
\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{r}_1-\mathbf{r}_2
\]
Both measured with respect to \(\mathcal{O}\).
These two formulas allow us to compute the new generalized coordinates \(\mathbf{R}\) and \(\mathbf{r}\) from \(\mathbf{r}_1\) and \(\mathbf{r}_2\). Inverting them we get:
\[
\begin{cases}
\mathbf{r}_1 = \mathbf{R} +\frac{m_2}{M}\mathbf{r}\\
\mathbf{r}_2 = \mathbf{R} -\frac{m_1}{M}\mathbf{r}
\end{cases}
\tag{2}\] we choose the reference frame attach located at \(\mathbf{R}\), i.e., we choose \(\mathcal{O} = \mathcal{O}_{cm}\), then Equation 2 becomes:
\[
\begin{cases}
\mathbf{r}_{1,cm} = \frac{m_2}{M}\mathbf{r}\\
\mathbf{r}_{2,cm} =  -\frac{m_1}{M}\mathbf{r}
\end{cases}
\tag{3}\]
where we introduce the subscript \(cm\) to reminds us that the components of these vectors are with respect to the new frame; absence of subscript, like in \(\mathbf{r}\) mean the components are with respect to the old reference frame.

title: collision theory intro
text:
Total Momentum
The total linear momentum of the particles is the sum of the momentum of particle \(1\) and \(2\). This quantity is related with \(\mathbf{R}\) as we see:
\[
\mathbf{P} = \mathbf{p}_1+\mathbf{p}_2=m_1\dot{\mathbf{r}}_1+m_2\dot{\mathbf{r}}_2=M\dot{\mathbf{R}}
\tag{4}\]
Differentiating we find:
\[
\dot{\mathbf{P}} = \mathbf{F}_{1,tot}+\mathbf{F}_{2,tot}=M\ddot{\mathbf{R}}
\]
The total force on \(1\) can be split into a sum of the external forces acting on \(1\) plus the force \(2\) does on \(1\), similar split is done for the particle \(2\). Since internal forces cancel, we know \(\mathbf{F}_{1,tot}+\mathbf{F}_{2,tot}=\mathbf{F}_{ext,tot}\). We conclude:
\[
\mathbf{F}_{ext,tot}=M\ddot{\mathbf{R}}
\] This formula has a very important consequence:

If the external forces are zero then the acceleration of the center of mass is zero.
If the acceleration of the center of mass is zero, then its velocity is zero or constant.
If the center of mass velocity is zero or constant, then a reference frame attach to it \(\mathcal{O}_{cm}\) is an inertial reference frame.

The frame \(\mathcal{O}_{cm}\) will be a useful definition when studying collisions. Because in this frame the components of velocity of the center of mass are zero \(\dot{\mathbf{R}}_{cm}=\mathbf{0}\) and as a result by Equation 4 we have:
\[
\begin{align}
&\mathbf{p}_1+\mathbf{p}_2=\mathbf{0}\\
\implies & \mathbf{p}_1=-\mathbf{p}_2
\end{align}
\tag{5}\]
Moreover, in this new frame the measurements of \(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_1\) and \(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_2\) become using Equation 3 :
\[ \begin{cases} \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{1,cm} = \frac{m_2}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}}\\ \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2,cm} =  -\frac{m_1}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}} \end{cases} \]
which leads us to explicit formulas for the linear momentum:
\[
\begin{cases}
\mathbf{p}_{1,cm} = m_1 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{1,cm} = \mu\dot{\mathbf{r}}\\
\mathbf{p}_{2,cm} = m_2 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2,cm} = -\mu\dot{\mathbf{r}}
\end{cases}
\tag{6}\]
As expected they satisfy the equation Equation 5 .

title: collision theory intro
text:
Kinetic Energy
The total kinetic energy of the particles is the sum of the kinetic energies, using the usual formulas we have wrt to any \(\mathcal{O}\):
\[
T = \frac{1}{2} m_1 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_1+\frac{1}{2} m_2 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_2
\]
As we have seen in Equation 2, from \(\mathbf{r}_1\) and \(\mathbf{r}_2\) we can compute the generalized coordinates \(\mathbf{R}\) and \(\mathbf{r}\). Differentiating, relates the velocities:
\[
\begin{cases}
\dot{\mathbf{r}}_1 = \dot{\mathbf{R}} +\frac{m_2}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}}\\
\dot{\mathbf{r}}_2 = \dot{\mathbf{R}} -\frac{m_1}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}}
\end{cases}
\]
These equations are valid for velocities measured wrt to any \(\mathcal{O}\) of our choice, they are general.
Substituting in \(T\) we find:
\[
T = \frac{1}{2} M\dot{\mathbf{R}}^2+\frac{1}{2} \mu\dot{\mathbf{r}}^2\qquad \mu = \frac{m_1m_2}{M}
\tag{7}\]
The total kinetic energy of \(1\) plus \(2\) at time \(t\) measured wrt to \(\mathcal{O}\) is equal to the sum of the kinetic energy of a massive particle \(M\) moving with velocity \(\dot{\mathbf{R}}\) plus a smaller particle \(\mu\) moving with velocity \(\dot{\mathbf{r}}\), both again, measured wrt to \(\mathcal{O}\).
The energy in Equation 7 is NOT the kinetic energy wrt to \(\mathcal{O}_{cm}\), it is just another way of computing the kinetic energy wrt to \(\mathcal{O}\). Note that both \(\dot{\mathbf{R}}\) and \(\dot{\mathbf{r}}\) have components with respect with the frame of reference.
If we choose the \(\mathcal{O}_{cm}\) frame of reference then \(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_1\) and \(\dot{\mathbf{r}}_2\) in Equation 3 become:
\[
\begin{cases}
\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{1,cm} = \frac{m_2}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}}\\
\dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2,cm} =  -\frac{m_1}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}}
\end{cases}
\]
These formulas are specific for velocities measured wrt center of mass reference frame.
The total kinetic energy as measured in \(\mathcal{O}_{cm}\) becomes after simplifying:
\[
T_{cm} = \frac{1}{2} m_1 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{1,cm}+\frac{1}{2} m_2 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_{2,cm} =  \frac{1}{2}\mu \dot{\mathbf{r}}^2
\]

title: collision theory intro
text:
Elastic Collisions
Our goal is to describe the momenta and kinetic energy in a two particle elastic collision. If we assume there is no external forces acting on the particles the center of mass position moves at constant velocity and therefore constitute a inertial reference frame \(\mathcal{O}_{cm}\). This is the first point of view we’ll adopt. The second point of view is a special case of a lab reference frame - the conventional lab frame for collisions - it is set in such a way that particle \(2\), the target is initially at rest. I would like to emphasize the key word initially at rest, that means that in the reference frame, after the collision, the particle \(2\) is no longer at rest.
See Fig. 14.14 Taylor

In \(\mathcal{O}_{cm}\) the initial and final momenta of both particles is given by Equation 6
\[
\begin{align}
\mathbf{p}_{1,cm} = -\mathbf{p}_{2,cm} \equiv \mathbf{p}_{cm}= \mu \dot{\mathbf{r}}\\
\mathbf{p}_{1,cm}' = -\mathbf{p}_{2,cm}' \equiv \mathbf{p}_{cm}'=\mu \dot{\mathbf{r}}'
\end{align}
\tag{8}\]
In \(\mathcal{O}_{lab}\) we find
\[
\begin{align}
&\mathbf{p}_{1,lab} =\lambda \mathbf{p}+\mathbf{p}\\
&\mathbf{p}_{1,lab}' = \lambda \mathbf{p}+\mathbf{p}'\qquad \lambda =\frac{m_1}{m_2}\\
&\mathbf{p}_{2,lab}=\mathbf{p}'_{2,lab}=\mathbf{0}
\end{align}
\]
proof: In this reference frame, \(\mathbf{p}_{1,lab} =m_1 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_1\) which when written in generalized coordinates of center of mass plus relative distance become:
\[
\begin{align}
\mathbf{p}_{1,lab} &=m_1 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_1\\
&=m_1(\dot{\mathbf{R}}+\frac{m_2}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}})\\
&=m_1\dot{\mathbf{R}}+\mu\dot{\mathbf{r}}
\end{align}
\tag{9}\]

Now, for particle \(2\) we also write \(\mathbf{p}_{2,lab} =m_2 \dot{\mathbf{r}}_2\), but since this particle is at rest in the lab frame we have \(\mathbf{p}_{2,lab}=\mathbf{0}\). Additionally, from the definition of center of mass Equation 1 we simplify Equation 9 using the observation that:
\[
\begin{cases}
\dot{\mathbf{R}} = \frac{m_1}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}}_1=\frac{m_1}{M}\dot{\mathbf{r}} =\frac{\mu}{m_2}\dot{\mathbf{r}}=\frac{\mathbf{p}}{m_2}\\
\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{r}_1-\mathbf{r}_2 = \mathbf{r}_1
\end{cases}
\tag{10}\]
where at the last step we used Equation 8; the momentum \(\mathbf{p}\) is of a fictitious particle with mass \(\mu\). Substituting this result in Equation 9 we find:
\[
\mathbf{p}_{1,lab} = m_1\dot{\mathbf{R}}+\mu\dot{\mathbf{r}}=\lambda \mathbf{p}+\mathbf{p}\qquad \lambda =\frac{m_1}{m_2}
\]
The momentum of \(1\) after collision has the same form as Equation 9 :
\[
\mathbf{p}'_{1,lab}=m_1\dot{\mathbf{R}}'+\mu\dot{\mathbf{r}}'
\tag{11}\]
Observe that \(\mu \dot{\mathbf{r}}'=\mathbf{p}'\); since \(\mathbf{F}_{1,ext}=\mathbf{0}\) then \(M\dot{\mathbf{R}} = M\dot{\mathbf{R}}'\), which means the velocity of the center of mass is the same before and after the collision and as a result we can compute it using Equation 10:
\[
\dot{\mathbf{R}}' = \dot{\mathbf{R}}=\frac{\mathbf{p}}{m_2}
\]
Substituting in Equation 11 yields:
\[
\mathbf{p}_{1,lab}' = \lambda \mathbf{p}+\mathbf{p}'\qquad \lambda =\frac{m_1}{m_2}
\]
The momentum of particle \(2\) after the collision is computed as:
\[
\begin{align}
\mathbf{p}_{2,lab}' &= \mathbf{p}_{1,lab}+\mathbf{p}_{2,lab}-\mathbf{p}_{1,lab}'\\
&=\lambda \mathbf{p}+\mathbf{p}+\mathbf{0}-\lambda \mathbf{p}-\mathbf{p}'\\
&=\mathbf{p}-\mathbf{p}'
\end{align}
\]
We further find that for this particular lab frame where \(2\) is at rest:
\[
T_{lab}=\frac{M}{m_2}T_{cm}
\]
proof: The kinetic energy after the collision is the sum of kinetic energies of both particles, particle \(2\) this time has nonzero kinetic energy, we can prove that this sum yields the result above, although an easier way is to notice that kinetic energy is conserved since the collision is elastic and computing the kinetic energy before the collision (when particle \(2\) is still at rest) is simple:
\[
\begin{align}
T_{lab}&=\frac{\mathbf{p}_{1,lab}^2}{2 m_1}+\frac{\mathbf{p}_{2,lab}^2}{2 m_2}\\
&=\frac{(\lambda \mathbf{p}+\mathbf{p})^2}{2m_1}+\mathbf{0}\\
&=\frac{(\lambda +1)^2}{2m_1}\mathbf{p}^2+\mathbf{0}\\
&=\frac{((m_1+m_2)/m_2)^2}{2m_1}\mathbf{p}^2\\
&=\frac{m_1}{2\mu^2}\mathbf{p}^2\\
&=\frac{M}{m_2}T_{cm}
\end{align}
\]
\[
\begin{align}
T&=\frac{\mathbf{p}_{1,lab}'^2}{2 m_1}+\frac{\mathbf{p}_{2,lab}'^2}{2 m_2}\\
&=\frac{(\lambda \mathbf{p}+\mathbf{p}')^2}{2m_1}+\frac{(\mathbf{p}-\mathbf{p}')^2}{2m_2}\\
&=
\end{align}
\]

title: collision theory intro
text:
Inelastic Collisions
In special relativity we know that the relativistic energy of a moving particle is given by:
\[
E = p_4c=\gamma m c^2\sim m c^2 +\frac{1}{2}m v^2\qquad v\ll c
\]
The limit being called the non-relativistic regime.
Consider a collision between two particles \(1\) and \(2\). If the system is isolated then there is conservation of four-momentum which implies conservation of relativistic energy, because this is the fourth component of four-momentum. In the non-relativistic regime the conservation of energy is:
\[
\begin{align}
&m_1^ic^2+\frac{1}{2}m_1^i(v_1^i)^2+m_2^ic^2+\frac{1}{2}m_2^i(v_2^i)^2 \\
&=m_1^fc^2+\frac{1}{2}m_1^f(v_1^f)^2+m_2^fc^2+\frac{1}{2}m_2^f(v_2^f)^2
\end{align}
\]
which is equivalent to:
\[
\begin{align}
&\overbrace{(m_1^i+m_2^i)}^{M^i}c^2+\overbrace{\frac{1}{2}m_1^i(v_1^i)^2+\frac{1}{2}m_2^i(v_2^i)^2}^{T^i} \\
&=\underbrace{(m_1^f+m_2^f)}_{M^f}c^2+\underbrace{\frac{1}{2}m_1^f(v_1^f)^2+\frac{1}{2}m_2^f(v_2^f)^2}_{T^f}
\end{align}
\tag{12}\]
If we assume, as we do in classical mechanics, that the mass of particles does not change then mass-energy terms cancel and the equality above reduces to:
\[
T^i=T^f
\]
The kinetic energy is conserved and we call it an elastic collision.
In an inelastic collision such as a collision between two atoms their internal energy (mass-energy terms) can be disturbed and as a result their kinetic energies before and after cannot be the same \(T^i\not = T^f\), as a result from Equation 12, the masses before and after cannot be the same \(M^i \not = M^f\).
If relativistic energy is conserved, then the mass cannot be conserved. When an atom gains internal energy, it gains mass.
The following formula Equation 12 is equivalent to:
\[
Q\equiv \Delta M c^2 =-\Delta T
\]
Here are some cases:

In an exothermic reaction \(\Delta T >0\), thus \(\Delta M<0\), the total rest mass of products of the reaction is smaller than the total mass of the reactants.
In an endothermic reaction the scenario signs are reversed.
In an elastic collision then \(\Delta T =0\) and as we have discussed the rest mass is unchanged \(\Delta M =0\).
Excitation reaction:
\[
e + Hg\longrightarrow e+Hg^*
\]
The electron does not change its mass due the collision because it has no internal structure, the mercury atom increases its quantum energy by \(4.9eV\), it becomes an excited atom. The kinetic energy of the emerging particles is smaller by \(4.9eV\), we write \(\Delta T = -4.9 eV\), thus:
\[
\begin{align}
&[(m^f_e+m^f_{Hg})-(m^i_e+m^i_{Hg})]c^2 = -\Delta T = 4.9 eV\\
\implies &[m^f_{Hg}-m^i_{Hg}]=\frac{4.9 eV}{c^2}=8.7\times 10^{-36}kg
\end{align}
\]

Different processes and Targets
When \(A_1\) collides with \(A_2\) other processes can occur:

It is scattered into a new direction, the effective area of \(A_2\) that causes this effect is called \(\sigma_{sc}\) (it is the \(\sigma\) seen above. This process can occur elastically, in this case, the kinetic energy of \(A_1\)is unchanged and so it the internal energy (mass-energy); or can occur inelatically, in this case the kinetic energy changes. We can introduce this distinction as:
\[
\sigma_{sc}=\sigma_{el}+\sigma_{inel}
\]
It is absorbed, if we imagine \(A_1\) hitting the region of \(A_2\) that is like putty, then \(A_1\) becomes part of \(A_1\), it is absorbed. In this case we define the effective region responsible for this effect as \(\sigma_{cap}\) and the relation between the incoming particles and those absorbed is
\[
N_{cap} = N_{inc} n_{tar} \sigma_{cap}
\]
It ionizes, in this case we define \(\sigma_{ion}\).

Example: When an electron hits a chlorine atom, it can either be scattered into a new direction, be absorbed (chlorine can absorb an extra electron) or be ionized (one electron from chlorine is removed). The overall relation is:
\[
N_{tot}= N_{inc}n_{tar}\sigma_{tot} \qquad \sigma_{tot} = \overbrace{\sigma_{el}+\sigma_{inel}}^{\sigma_{sc}}+\sigma_{cap}+\sigma_{ion}
\]
Each one of these effective cross section depends on the kinetic energy of the inc electron, for example:
\[
\sigma_{ion}=
\begin{cases}
\text{positive }\qquad &T_{inc}\geq E_{ionization}\\
0\qquad &T_{inc}<E_{ionization}
\end{cases}
\]
The energy of ionization is the energy (eigenvalue) is the energy of the outermost electron (wave function with largest radius)

title: Special Relativity
text:
Galilean Transformation
Consider a set of reference frames that move at relative constant velocity. Let us deduce a particular and simple case of Galilean transformations between two frames, this simple case is a consequence of the following assumption on the two chosen frames:

The frames S and S’ are oriented in such a way that the x,y,z-axes are parallel and they move with velocity \(V\) along the x axis, see Fig. 15.1
S and S’ are equipped with a clock, to measure time and both clocks measure \(t=t'=0\) when initially both frames’s origin coincide.

As a result we have the following relation between measurements \((x,y,z,t)\) and \((x',y',z',t')\):
\[
\begin{cases}
x' =x-Vt\\
y'=y\\
z'=z\\
t'=t
\end{cases}
\]
A generalization of these formulas for two frames where \(V\) has any direction \(\mathbf{V}\) is
\[
\mathbf{r}'=\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{V}t \qquad t'=t
\tag{1}\]
Further generalizations are possible if we allow the two frame’s axes to be non-parallel but rotated, but the formula above suffices.
Differentiating the relation we find:
\[
\mathbf{v}'=\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{V}
\tag{2}\]

title: Special Relativity
text:
Time Dilation
Consider the train situation with the two frames S and S’.
S is inertial and thus S’ is inertial, therefore the law distance = velocity \(\times\) time holds in both. In particular for S’
\[
\Delta t' =\frac{2h}{c}
\]
Using again the rule distance = velocity \(\times\) time in S we find the lengths of the sides of the triangle, which in turn are related by
\[
(\frac{c\Delta t}{2})^2=h^2+(\frac{V\Delta t}{2})^2
\]
which is equivalent to:
\[
\Delta t = \frac{2h}{c}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^2}} \qquad \beta = \frac{V}{c}
\]
We conclude:
\[
\Delta t = \frac{\Delta t'}{\sqrt{1-\beta^2}}
\]
Two events occurring at the same place in S’ separated by \(\Delta t'\) seconds are seen in S as being separated by \(\Delta t\) seconds.
We want to reformulate this expression, define
\[
\gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^2}}
\]
and \(\Delta t_0:= \Delta t'\) the time elapsed in the reference frame (in this case S’) where the event occurred at the same place.
Thus:
\[
\Delta t = \gamma \Delta t_0\geq \Delta t_0
\]
since \(\gamma \geq 1\).
We should think about this formula as:
\[
[\text{time elaspsed measured in two places}] = \gamma\times [\text{time elapsed measured at same place}]
\tag{3}\]

Átomo era indivisível (Maxwell 1872)
1899 - Thomson nos seus estudos da condução de electricidade observa que átomo é divisível, a corrente eléctrica evolve movimento livre de partes (electrões) de um átomo
Experiências com radioactividade realizadas por Marie Curie (1867- 1934), Ernest Rutherford (1871-1937) e Frederick Soddy apontam também para divisibilidade do átomo. Descobriu-se que a transformação radioactiva dos átomos envolve a emissão de partículas pelos átomos (partículas subatómicas)
Em 1910 as experiências de Lenard mostraram que electrões conseguem atravessar folhas de metal finas, mostrando assim que átomos são porosos.
Descoberta que cada elemento tem-lhe associado uma serie espectral, i.e., um conjunto de comprimentos de onda de radiação emitida. Tal sugere que deve haver movimento de cargas no interior dos átomos.

Todas estas descobertas levaram ao desenvolvimento de modelos do átomo:
